title: Sampling Distribution of a Sample Mean: Honeytown
question_text:
A survey conducted in Honeytown found that the average number of people per household was $4.3$ with a standard deviation of $1.2$. The true average size and standard deviation of a household in Honeytown is $4.1$ and $0.98$ respectively.
Using simple random samples of size $50$, what are the mean and standard deviation for the sampling distribution of the sample means of the number of people per household in Honeytown?
solution:
Sampling distribution refers to the distribution of values taken by a statistic in all possible samples of the same size from the same population.

First, let us find the mean of the sampling distribution of the sample means(${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }$).

The formula which is given on the AP Exam is:

$${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=\mu $$

...where $\mu $ represents the population average.

So in this case,

$${ \mu }_{ \overline { x } }=\mu= 4.1$$

Choices 'D' and 'E' can be eliminated.

The formula(also given on AP Exam) for the standard deviation for the sampling distribution of sample means is given by:

$$\sigma _{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { \sigma }{ \sqrt { n } } $$

...where $\sigma $ represents the population standard deviation

In our case,

$$\sigma _{ \overline { x } }=\dfrac { 0.98 }{ \sqrt { 50 } }$$

Choice 'A' is our answer.
